runs.summary: Nneka (host) discusses guest Brad's rescheduling friction, revealing pricing opacity, off-platform communication via text, and the replace-vs-add ambiguity. Analyzed through Kahneman's System 1/System 2 framework: ego depletion across 13+ weekly Stays Manager visits, law of least effort driving guests off-platform, anchoring on original rates creating mid-lease betrayal perception, and the bat-and-ball problem applied to pricing format translation.

Andreas — investor host with 2 units in Washington Heights (found via Craigslist). Analyzed through Kahneman's System 1/System 2 framework: cognitive ease, ego depletion, anchoring, and the law of least effort applied to the host onboarding and listing flow.

Jessica Filomeno — real estate broker evaluating Split Lease as a B2B inventory sourcing partnership. Analyzed through Cialdini's Authority/Liking/Scarcity framework: trust-gated decision-making, honest constraint feedback as liking tactic, scarcity validation through demand proof, and broker approval as structural dropout risk.

Drew — Chelsea 1BR/1BA host ($2,000/month, $1,000 deposit, 4-month term) who found Split Lease through a friend, comfortable with shared living. Analyzed through Krug's Don't Make Me Think usability framework: self-evident navigation eliminating cognitive overhead, Billboard Design for scannable listing pages, visual affordance vocabulary making clickable elements unmistakable, trunk test for page identification, and reducing happy talk in favor of actionable content at every journey phase.

Zella Myers — CCNY employee seeking Wednesday-Saturday housing near 125th-145th St in Manhattan. Analyzed through Cialdini's commitment and social proof framework: reveals how the guest journey lacks reciprocal value for micro-commitments, has zero social proof at uncertainty points, creates passive waiting that erodes commitment, and fails to establish platform comprehension before consequential actions. The lens exposes that split-lease's inherent novelty makes social proof the single most critical missing element in the guest experience.

lens.book: Influence The Psychology of Persuasion - Robert Cialdini.pdf
lens.book_chapters: Chapters 3-4: Commitment & Consistency + Social Proof

runs.summary: Airbnb reverse benchmark through Cialdini Chapters 3-4 (Commitment & Consistency + Social Proof). Identified 10 disappointments across 3 clusters: the Commitment Architecture Gap (booking as transaction not relationship), the Similarity Blindspot (mass social proof vs. people-like-you proof), and the Identity Void (no guest self-concept). Produced 6 UI elements: Mutual Pledge Card, People-Like-You Review Filter, Pre-Arrival Conversation Guide, Post-Review Forward Commitment Bridge, Stay Purpose Selector, and Commitment Reassurance Badge. 11 reinforcements with existing library elements confirmed cross-process validation.

This dual lens reveals how signalling trust through costly investment and designing habit loops intersect with platform adoption across both guest and host journeys, with particular emphasis on how minimal viable commitment conflicts with trust-building mechanisms.
This dual lens reveals that both guests and hosts are satisficing under uncertainty while being shaped by choice architecture they don't recognize as nudges.

This dual lens reveals the fundamental perceptual gap between how Split Lease presents itself and how users actually process information under cognitive constraints. The guest call (Stephen) shows a mid-conversion abandonment driven by uncertainty and lack of immediate recognition cues. The host call (David) shows successful conversion through simplicity and zero-friction commitment. Psychophysics principles expose that users evaluate Split Lease's legitimacy through packaging (presentation), not just product (service value). Weinschenk's attention and memory research reveals that both guests and hosts operate with severely limited working memory (4 items at once), selective attention (10-minute sustained max), and unconscious decision-making.

Tapper S — seasonal worker couple (Bryant Park holiday booth) seeking 2.5-month stay in Manhattan with wife and dog, $2,500/month budget. Analyzed through Saffer's Microinteractions framework (Triggers, Rules, Feedback, Loops/Modes): reveals how the stay-by-stay review system can be designed as lightweight micro-interactions that generate 10x review volume without burdening users. Key insight: cleaning photo submission is the natural system trigger for reviews, and long loops progressively simplify reviews from 60 seconds (first stay) to 5 seconds (one-tap 'Same as last time') by stay 5+. The lens also exposes pricing confusion (per-bedroom vs full-unit) and the gap between human agent guidance and platform self-service.

lens.book_chapters: Part 1, Chapters 1-4: Why Great Firms Fail

runs.summary: Airbnb reverse benchmark through Christensen's Innovator's Dilemma Part 1 (Ch 1-4). Airbnb's upmarket migration into luxury vacation experiences created three structurally undefended vacuums: the relationship layer (no platform treats the host-guest bond as the product), the active-stay layer (zero management between booking and review), and the trust-formation layer (no cohabitation compatibility assessment). 11 disappointments identified, 4 with strong transcript validation (5+ transcripts each). 4 new discoveries including 'The Airbnb Burnout Exodus' — hosts actively fleeing Airbnb. 5 opportunities ranked, led by 'The Relationship-First Platform' (the person is the listing). 6 UI elements produced, all reinforcing existing library patterns. The Total Monthly Cost Badge achieved the strongest cross-process signal in the system: 5 independent lenses across 2 process types converge on it.

lens.book_chapters: Part 2, Chapters 5-7: Managing Disruptive Technological Change

runs.summary: Zillow reverse benchmark through Christensen's Innovator's Dilemma Part 2 (Ch 5-7). Zero Zillow mentions across 68 user transcripts — the strongest possible Christensen validation that Zillow is structurally invisible to the mid-term shared housing market. 10 disappointments identified across the Dehumanization Complex, Temporal Blindness Syndrome, Agency Inversion, and Lifecycle Abandonment clusters. 5 opportunities led by 'Schedule-Native Housing' (14 transcript validations, the most heavily validated finding). 7 UI elements produced including the Week-Pattern Search Filter and Ghost Roommate Trust Profile Card. Triple convergence achieved on schedule-native housing across all analytical processes. The Three-Tap Date Swap Card flagged as design-complete — independently produced near-identical specs from both pipelines.

lens.book_chapters: Chapters 8-9: Capabilities, Disabilities & Performance Oversupply

runs.summary: Facebook Marketplace reverse benchmark through Christensen's Innovator's Dilemma Ch 8-9 (RPV Framework & Performance Oversupply). Marketplace has massive distribution but its Resources, Processes, and Values are built for general commerce — its 'good enough' housing listings are performance oversupply for browsing but catastrophically insufficient for trust-based shared housing. 10 disappointments identified, 9 validated by transcripts (4 strong). 5 opportunities led by 'Schedule-Native Housing: The Disruptive Beachhead.' 7 UI elements produced. Zero contradictions with existing library — the strongest coherence result. 3 gold-level cross-process insights: trust gate convergence, schedule-first convergence, and confirm-not-construct convergence. The Returning Guest Relationship Card fills the largest gap between strategic importance and library coverage.

lens.book_chapters: Chapters 1-5: The Complete Hook Model

runs.summary: Booking.com reverse benchmark through Nir Eyal's Hooked (Ch 1-5: Hook Model) with special focus on REVIEWS for long-term shared housing. The Hook Model reveals that Booking.com's review system is a single-pass extraction tool — it fires one trigger at checkout, demands high-friction action, offers zero variable reward, and stores no investment value. For 3+ month leases (max 4 reviews/year), every Hook phase breaks. 12 disappointments identified across 4 clusters: The Broken Hook Cycle, The Mid-Stay Data Desert, The Reviewer Identity Vacuum, and The Long-Stay Relevance Gap. 68 transcripts scanned with 32 yielding matches; 7 strong validations including the Trust Desert (6 transcripts). 4 new discoveries: LinkedIn-as-trust-workaround, vetting-as-invisible-review, physical-verification demand, and Airbnb refugee trust loop. 5 opportunities ranked, led by 'The Stay-Cycle Review Heartbeat' — one-tap micro-reviews in the Stays Manager accumulating 13+ data points per lease. 7 UI elements produced. 7 cross-process reinforcements found, strongest being the Stays Manager convergence (design-stack via Kahneman + reverse-benchmark via Eyal independently identify it as foundational architecture). 1 productive contradiction (ego depletion vs habit formation) resolved into a two-layer system: high-frequency pulses + periodic syntheses.

lens.book_chapters: Chapter 1: Affordances, Signifiers, Mapping, Feedback, and Conceptual Models

runs.summary: Susan Bryant — booking for a friend from Oregon, 1-2 month weekday stay for medical appointments. Analyzed through Don Norman's affordances/signifiers/feedback framework: reveals that the platform's system image is incoherent to first-time users, with missing signifiers at every phase forcing a human intermediary (Bryant) to serve as the primary affordance. Susan misidentifies the service as a real estate brokerage. The lens exposes catastrophic discoverability failures, absent feedback loops during proposal/negotiation, and a conceptual model gap where the non-continuous nights model has no perceivable signifiers. 7 UI elements produced including Platform Identity Hero Section, Listing Trust Verification Stack, Space Composition Listing Card, Natural-Language Stay Configurator, Proposal Negotiation Timeline, Booking Confirmation with Next-Steps Roadmap, and Move-In House Manual with Verification Checklist.

lens.book_chapters: All chapters: Usability Laws and Design Principles

runs.summary: SpareRoom reverse benchmark through Krug's Don't Make Me Think (all chapters). Krug's usability framework reveals that SpareRoom forces users to think at nearly every critical decision point — from ambiguous navigation labels and cluttered search results to opaque messaging norms and absent post-move lifecycle support. The analysis exposes a category-wide assumption that flatmate-finding is a one-time transaction rather than a relationship-dependent experience. SpareRoom's 20+ years of brand trust masks deep usability failures: the 'Buddy Up' label violates Krug's self-evidence rule, search results prioritize listing volume over scannability, and the platform completely abandons users after move-in. 7 UI elements produced including People-First Listing Hero, Scaffolded First Contact Card, Commitment Journey Breadcrumb, Host Turnover Checklist, Portable Reputation Timeline, How Split Lease Works Self-Evident Explainer, and Emotional Milestone Toast.

lens.book_chapters: Part 1: The Category King Economy (Chapters 1-2) — Creation Wins, Category Is the New Strategy

runs.summary: Craigslist reverse benchmark through Play Bigger Category Design (Part 1, Chapters 1-2). The run identifies four signature opportunities for Split Lease category leadership: commute-cost framing, compounding trust ledger infrastructure, structured proposal protocol, and an active-stay operating layer. Produced 4 UI elements with cross-process reinforcements against existing design-stack patterns.

lens.book_chapters: Part 2: Heuristics and Biases — Law of Small Numbers, Anchoring, Availability

runs.summary: Tammy — professional host managing 13-14 units in Harlem/Queens, $5,000/month per 2BR target, strong Airbnb aversion (prefers VRBO for host control), seasonal vacancy Jan-April. Analyzed through Kahneman Part 2 (anchoring, availability, law of small numbers): reveals that per-night pricing anchors hosts on insufficient income, the availability heuristic creates an 'Airbnb betrayal cascade' that biases evaluation against all platforms, and the law of small numbers means the platform was likely designed from small host samples excluding multi-property professionals. 6 UI elements produced including Paired-Tenant Income Calculator, Guest Trust Profile Proposal Card, Host Policy Sovereignty Panel, Portfolio Income Dashboard, Seasonal Vacancy-to-Income Comparison, and Anti-Airbnb Platform Differentiation Hero. Strong reinforcements with existing library: income anchor typography merges with Single-Number Financial Focal Point, and multi-property portfolio extends batch operations to professional scale.

lens.book_chapters: Part 1: The Cold Start Problem and Atomic Networks

runs.summary: Roomi reverse benchmark through Cold Start network-effects lens (Part 1). The run found four category-level opportunities: neighborhood liquidity proof, structured commitment rail, 48-hour anti-ghosting protocol, and portable post-stay reputation. Produced 4 UI elements and cross-process reinforcements with existing trust, communication, and cognitive-load patterns.

lens.book_chapters: Part 4: Choices — Prospect Theory, Loss Aversion, Endowment Effect, Rare Events

runs.summary: Steve Zhang — digital nomad / multi-local professional (Airtable, Troy MI), no permanent lease, house-sitting in Boston, storing belongings with friends. Analyzed through Kahneman Part 4 (prospect theory, loss aversion, endowment effect, certainty effect): reveals that guests evaluate every booking decision relative to a reference point (current status quo of hotel-hopping or couch-surfing), loss aversion makes them overweight the risk of committing to an unknown space (~2x), and the endowment effect means once they mentally 'own' a listing configuration they resist counter-offers. 6 UI elements produced: Gain-Frame Listing Price Card (reframes cost as savings vs hotels), Plan Your Stay Interactive Configurator (creates endowment before commitment), Preserved-First Counter-Offer Display (protects endowment during negotiation), Certainty Timeline with Post-Acceptance States (eliminates uncertainty gaps), Active Lease Savings Dashboard (running gain-frame reinforcement), and Protection Shield Module (certainty effect for trust).

lens.book_chapters: Chapters 1-5: Challenge of the Future, Party Like 1999, All Happy Companies Are Different, Ideology of Competition, Last Mover Advantage

runs.summary: Furnished Finder reverse benchmark through Peter Thiel's Zero to One (Ch 1-5: Monopoly, Competition, Last Mover). FF has a genuine monopoly in travel nurse housing via flat-fee model + SEO dominance + healthcare employer verification. But Thiel's framework reveals structural vulnerabilities: zero proprietary technology (basic listings), no network effects (users don't benefit from more users), no economies of scale in trust (every transaction is independent). FF is doing 1-to-n (copying Craigslist model for nurses) not 0-to-1. Split Lease's contrarian truth: mid-term housing is not a listing problem but a relationship and trust infrastructure problem. 6 UI elements produced: Trust Ledger Profile Card, Extension Flow Card, Smart Agreement Builder, Host Differentiation Tier Badge, Availability Truth Indicator, and Housing Career Dashboard.

lens.book_chapters: Introduction + Chapters 1-3: Choice Architecture, Defaults, and Framing

runs.summary: Roomster reverse benchmark through Nudge choice-architecture lens (Introduction + Chapters 1-3). The run surfaced four opportunities: trust-first legitimacy ladder, probability-aware search defaults, guided commitment rail, and an outcome-memory retention loop. Produced 4 UI elements with cross-process reinforcements around trust sequencing, pricing clarity, and lifecycle scaffolding.

lens.book_chapters: Introduction + Chapters 1-2: Weapons of Influence, Reciprocation (The Old Give and Take)

runs.summary: Sherene — Brooklyn host considering ghost roommate arrangement (Greg weekdays, Johan weekends, 6 nights/week). Analyzed through Cialdini's Reciprocation framework: Bryant's 27-minute call is a masterclass in give-first psychology — 9 cascading small gifts (scenario walkthrough, cleaning solution, separate sheets idea, price concession, lockbox, photo documentation, hosted interviews, daily payment, relationship management) create compound obligation that keeps Sherene engaged despite core anxiety about rotating strangers. The lens reveals that every successful phase transition in the host journey requires the platform to give before it asks. Key discoveries: rejection-then-retreat fallback flows for high-commitment gates, three-party reciprocity ledger for ghost roommate arrangements, Thursday handoff protocol as the highest-anxiety interaction in shared housing, and daily payment notifications as continuous reciprocity reinforcement. 7 UI elements produced including Gift-First Onboarding Card, Ghost Roommate Guest Profile Card, Contrast-Anchored Pricing Display, Daily Payment Notification Card, Thursday Handoff Tracker, Rejection-Then-Retreat Listing Simplifier, and Cumulative Gift Ledger for Retention.

lens.book_chapters: Chapters 1-5: Why Lean UX, Principles, Vision/Framing/Outcomes, Collaborative Design, MVPs and Experiments

runs.summary: Sonder reverse benchmark through Lean UX hypothesis-driven design framework. The Lean UX lens reveals that Sonder built an entire company on untested assumptions about mid-term housing — scaling outputs (more units, more cities) rather than validating outcomes (better stays, stronger relationships). Every Sonder design decision is an untested hypothesis: apartment-hotel format, anonymous support queues, temporal flatness (night 1 = night 30), zero post-stay learning, no neighborhood integration. Steve Zhang directly complained about Sonder's anonymous support. 10 disappointments in 3 clusters (Relationship Void, Temporal Flatline, Untested Model), 8/10 validated by transcripts, 3 new discoveries (Rescheduling Gap, Trust-Before-Commitment Pattern, Commuter Identity). 5 opportunities ranked, led by Relationship-First Anti-Sonder and Temporal Stay Arc. 6 UI elements produced: Relationship Timeline Card, Temporal Stay Arc Banner, Hypothesis Confidence Meter, Commuter Schedule Matcher, Neighborhood Knowledge Feed, and Outcomes Dashboard. 5 cross-process reinforcements with zero contradictions — Stays Manager convergence now at 6+ independent signals from both process types.

lens.book_chapters: Part 1: The Category King Economy (Chapters 1-2) — Creation Wins, Category Is the New Strategy

runs.summary: Roomster reverse benchmark through Play Bigger category-design lens (Part 1, Chapters 1-2). The run identifies four signature opportunities: pre-contact legitimacy chain, guided commitment-state rail, availability truth timeline, and an outcome-compounding debrief loop. Produced 4 UI elements with cross-process reinforcements around trust sequencing, negotiation clarity, and lifecycle learning.

lens.book_chapters: Chapters 3-4: Commitment and Consistency, Social Proof

runs.summary: Tamycka — brand ambassador from New Haven CT, commuter with 2 children (5mo + 6yr), price-sensitive, Thu-Fri-Sat schedule. Analyzed through Cialdini's Commitment & Consistency and Social Proof frameworks: micro-commitment escalation ladders, similarity-based social proof for family verification, written commitment reinforcement, price transparency as anti-lowball, and child safety verification badges. Reveals that budget-constrained parents need total-cost-first pricing, family-specific social proof at the point of listing evaluation, and weekly micro-reviews to accumulate a temporal narrative.

lens.book_chapters: All sections: How People See, Read, Remember, Think, Focus Attention, Motivations, Social Animals, Emotions, Mistakes, Decisions

runs.summary: HotPads reverse benchmark through Weinschenk's 100 Things Every Designer Needs to Know About People. HotPads excels at search but has no active-stay experience. 11 disappointments in 4 clusters: Faceless Storyless Void, Cognitive Overload Without Scaffolding, Black Box After Interest, Abandoned Lifecycle. 22 transcripts matched with 4 strong validations and 3 new discoveries (Human Agent as Missing Layer, Navigation Confusion, Trust Transfer Problem). 5 opportunities identified. 7 UI elements produced including Host Identity Card, Narrative Listing Description, Search Session Memory Bar, Comparison Tray, Proposal Status Pipeline, Active Stay Weekly Check-In Card, and Resident Social Proof Badge.

lens.book_chapters: Introduction + Chapters 1-6: Wisdom of Crowds, Diversity, Independence/Imitation, Decentralization, Coordination, Trust/Cooperation

runs.summary: Anthony — passive landlord, 157 W 80th St UWS, $3,000/mo, no photos, AOL email, 6-minute monosyllabic call. Analyzed through Surowiecki's Wisdom of Crowds: reveals the 'missing voter' problem — passive hosts contribute zero signal to collective intelligence because platform aggregation mechanisms (web forms, uploads) don't match their preferred channels (SMS, phone). Five cross-phase patterns: aggregation mechanism mismatch, agent-dependency creating information cascades, monosyllabic signal revealing radically simpler decision criteria, and decentralization without aggregation. Key innovations: SMS-first passive-host aggregation pipeline, agent-to-platform data bridge auto-populating listings from calls, co-host mode for passive landlords, crowd-calibrated pricing, and silence interpretation framework.

lens.book_chapters: Cold Start Theory Framework + Chapters 4-10: Tiny Speck/Slack, Tipping Point, Escape Velocity, Hitting the Ceiling, The Moat

runs.summary: PadSplit reverse benchmark through Andrew Chen's Cold Start Theory (Ch 4-10). PadSplit solved the metro-level Cold Start Problem through institutional supply-side infrastructure (standardized room conversions, host insurance, compliance management) but failed at the house level — their atomic network (housemates in a single property) has no social dynamic, no magic moment, no engagement ladder. 10 disappointments in 3 clusters: The Missing Atomic Network (houses as inventory not communities), The Engagement Void (no ladder, no anchor, no retention flywheel), The Missing Moat (disposable reputation, perpetual cold starts). 15 transcripts validated. 3 new discoveries: Trust Bridge, Airbnb Grievance, Multi-Local Identity. 5 opportunities: House Atomic Network, Engagement Ladder, Shared Housing Passport, House Anchor System, Magic Moment Social Search. 7 UI elements produced. Stays Manager convergence now at 8+ independent signals.

lens.book_chapters: Hierarchy, Layout and Spacing, Typography, Color, Depth and Shadows, Working with Images, Finishing Touches

runs.summary: Dana — flight attendant host with a full existing Furnished Finder listing, negative experience with a fish-cooking WFH tenant. Analyzed through Refactoring UI's visual hierarchy framework: reveals that time-fragmented hosts (5-second check-ins between flights) need glanceable status dashboards with guest-type day-badges as primary visual hierarchy, spacing-as-hierarchy for information layers, and async communication tiers. The lens exposes that listing import flows and negative-preference filtering are critical for cross-platform hosts.

lens.book_chapters: Chapters 1-5: The Hook Model — Trigger, Action, Variable Reward, Investment

runs.summary: Tyler Wood — Saturday-Wednesday weekly commuter for 2+ months. Analyzed through Eyal's Hook Model: the weekly stay cycle maps directly to a 4-phase Hook loop (trigger→action→variable reward→investment), creating 8+ engagement cycles per lease. The platform currently captures zero guest preferences (all given verbally to an agent), producing zero switching costs. Key innovations: day-of-week flexibility selector, guest investment capture via auto-built preference profiles, weekly stay check-in as one-tap action, cleaning photo exchange as investment, and price decomposition with day-rate transparency. Craigslist-to-platform bridge addresses Tyler's discovery path.

lens.book_chapters: Introduction + Chapters 1-6: Libertarian Paternalism, Choice Architecture, Defaults, Framing, Status Quo Bias

runs.summary: Kris — high-value NYC delegator-host who operates through proxies (girlfriend manages account, agent handles photos/pricing). Analyzed through Thaler & Sunstein's Nudge framework: every blank field is a failed default, loss aversion about property assets (art collection) outweighs income excitement 2:1, smart defaults beat choices for delegator-hosts, and phone calls serve as choice architecture bypass that the platform should internalize.

lens.book_chapters: Forms, Buttons, Components: Action Hierarchy, Semantics, Form Design, Tables, Dropdowns

runs.summary: William Romano — cautious guest with cleanliness anxiety about shared living. Analyzed through Refactoring UI's forms/buttons/components framework: three-tier action hierarchy (primary/secondary/tertiary) prevents decision paralysis, non-binding language ('Send Your Interest' not 'Submit Proposal') reduces proposal friction, generous spacing systems build trust, and the Stays Manager command center needs clear action hierarchy for 13+ weekly visits.

lens.book_chapters: Part 1-3: Cold Start Problem, Tipping Point, Escape Velocity — Network Effects, Atomic Networks, Invitation Mechanics

runs.summary: Dimitri — 8-year NYC host (30th St, Hudson Yards), traveling to Europe July-October, explicit third-party skepticism ('I usually don't deal with third parties'), demands driver's license verification, wants things done 'within next week.' Analyzed through Andrew Chen's Cold Start Problem (Parts 1-3): Dimitri IS the hard side of the network, and his third-party skepticism is the exact friction that kills atomic networks before they tip. Key innovations: magic link match-first onboarding (show demand before platform), dual verification transparency (platform vetting + personal documents side by side), time-bounded atomic network formation (convert within urgency window or lose host), remote overseas host monitoring via push-first status architecture, and traditional sublease vocabulary translation. 7 UI elements produced with compounding: Host-Sees-Guest-Perspective Card, Micro-Review Prompt Card, In-Platform Chat Thread with Agent Context, Guest Arrival House Manual Card, Host Notification Escalation Timeline, Weekly Calendar Strip with Stay Visualization, and Magic Link Match Preview Page. All 6 identified library gaps filled (cross-journey, review/rating, messaging, house manual, notifications, calendar).

lens.book_chapters: Chapters 1-8: Articulating Design Decisions, Severity Framework, Stakeholder Communication, Design Rationale

runs.summary: Theodore Matthews — cautious guest who compares Split Lease to Airbnb, analyzed through Tom Greever's Articulating Design Decisions severity framework. Friction points ranked by severity: platform identity confusion (critical), pricing opacity (critical), trust deficit (major), move-in anxiety (major). Compounding run filling 6 library gaps: cross-journey perspective bridge, matching pipeline tracker, weekly savings micro-review, digital house manual, guest notification center, and calendar week view.

lens.book_chapters: The Design of Everyday Things — Affordances, Signifiers, Mapping, Feedback, and Conceptual Models

runs.summary: hemeden (host) analyzed through donnorman-affordances-signifiers-feedback. 7 UI elements, 47 principles generated.

lens.book_chapters: Cognitive Ease — Illusions of Remembering, Illusions of Truth, How to Write a Persuasive Message, Strain and Effort, The Pleasure of Cognitive Ease, Ease Mood and Intuition

runs.summary: diane-kaufhold (host) analyzed through kahneman-cognitive-ease. 7 UI elements, 53 principles generated.

lens.book_chapters: Enjoyment and the Quality of Life — Pleasure and Enjoyment, The Elements of Enjoyment, The Autotelic Experience

runs.summary: Shomit Ghosh - 8 April 2022 (guest) analyzed through flow-enjoyment-quality. 7 UI elements, 59 principles generated.

lens.book_chapters: Social Proof — Truths Are Us, Cause of Death: Uncertainty, Devictimizing Yourself, Monkey Me Monkey Do, How to Say No

runs.summary: john (host) analyzed through cialdini-social-proof. 7 UI elements, 47 principles generated.

lens.book_chapters: Choice Architecture — Stimulus-Response Compatibility, Make It Easy, Defaults, Expect Error, Give Feedback, Understanding Mappings, Structure Complex Choices, Incentives

runs.summary: Sophie Charvet - 18 April 2022 (guest) analyzed through nudge-choice-architecture. 7 UI elements, 66 principles generated.

lens.book_chapters: Departure — The Call to Adventure, Refusal of the Call, Supernatural Aid, The Crossing of the First Threshold, The Belly of the Whale

runs.summary: kent (host) analyzed through campbell-departure-heros-journey. 7 UI elements, 68 principles generated.

lens.book_chapters: Chapters III and V: Sources of Unhappiness (nature, body, human relationships) + Individual Instinct vs Civilization Demands

runs.summary: The Freud lens reveals the host journey as a graduated negotiation between instinctual freedom (the host's desire to control their private space) and civilizational participation (the marketplace's demand that they share it with vetted strangers). Every phase requires a new act of renunciation that the platform must make psychologically viable through proportional value delivery. The seven UI elements synthesize this insight across all layers: a value-first discovery earnings card that protects pre-civilizational curiosity, a listing wizard with dignified progress preservation, an urgency-first host dashboard structured as civilizational order, a proposal review card that resolves stranger-threat anxiety through trust-before-terms architecture, a bidirectional protection dialog that makes platform constraints feel like mutual safety, a stay cycle ritual card that contains active-lease anxiety through predictable repetition, and a cumulative hosting summary that counteracts the narcissism of minor differences at retention. Together they form a coherent system where every instinctual sacrifice is compensated, every constraint is bidirectional, and every ritual confirms the civilizational contract is holding.

lens.book_chapters: Chapter 4: The Conditions of Flow - Flow Activities, Flow and Culture, The Autotelic Personality, The People of Flow

runs.summary: The user-stories analysis crossed with Csikszentmihalyi's Conditions of Flow reveals that the guest journey systematically violates all four flow prerequisites -- clear goals, immediate feedback, challenge-skill balance, and sense of control -- at every phase transition. Discovery lacks the 'distinct world' quality that separates flow activities from everyday browsing. Search cards offer flat, static information that bores guests whose skills outgrow them. The gap between listing evaluation and proposal creation has no intermediate challenge (messaging) to bridge anxiety. The proposal form maximizes self-consciousness through blank fields. Negotiation reduces a collaborative agon to a binary verdict. And the Stays Manager -- visited 13+ times per lease -- has no complexity ratchet to prevent mid-lease boredom. These seven UI elements address each structural flow failure with buildable components that synthesize works-layer process patterns, communicates-layer information architecture, looks-layer visual grammar, behaves-layer interaction timing, and feels-layer emotional design into production-ready specifications.

Cross-run critique comparing HOST (Freud) and GUEST (Flow) runs on the same user stories input. Identified 8 phase gaps (move-in critical), 10 element quality issues (pricing arithmetic error, incomplete Stays Manager lifecycle), 7 blind spots (inline auth modal missing), 6 contradictions, and 32 reinforcements. Stays Manager confirmed as most theoretically reinforced component (5 independent lenses). Top 3 actions: fix pricing model, build inline auth modal, design move-in phase.

lens.book_chapters: Chapter 2: The Tree of Knowledge — Cognitive Revolution, shared myths, intersubjective trust, cooperation through collective fiction

runs.summary: user-stories-initial-analysis.md (guest) analyzed through sapiens-tree-of-knowledge. 7 UI elements, 45 principles generated.
